thread.title: USA Gymnastics Launches Independent Inquiry in Case of Larry Nassar - NBC News
thread.title_full: USA Gymnastics Launches Independent Inquiry in Case of Larry Nassar - NBC News

author: Alex Johnson
title: USA Gymnastics Launches Independent Inquiry in Case of Larry Nassar - NBC News

organizations.name: et usa gymnastics launches independent inquiry

text:
Feb 19 2017, 7:29 pm ET USA Gymnastics Launches Independent Inquiry in Case of Larry Nassar by Alex Johnson Former USA Gymnastics Doctor Accused of Sexually Abusing Dozens of Women 2:23 autoplay autoplay Copy this code to your website or blog <iframe src="http://www.nbcnews.com/widget/video-embed/879920707544" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> 
The governing body for gymnastics in the United States has appointed a former assistant attorney general to independently review its bylaws and policies after its longtime doctor Larry Nassar was charged with criminal sexual conduct and possessing child pornography. 
Dr. Larry Nassar, 53, has pleaded not guilty to state charges in Michigan of sexual assault and federal charges of possession of more than 37,000 images of child pornography. Separately, more than 60 former patients have also filed police complaints alleging that Nassar, a sports medicine doctor, molested them under the guise of pelvic procedures. 
Nassar was fired by USA Gymnastics, which oversees national competitive gymnastics, and by Michigan State University, where he had his practice. Gymnastics doctor Larry Nassar appears in court Friday in Michigan on sex abuse charges. NBC News 
In a statement Sunday — shortly before three elite U.S. gymnasts outlined their allegations on CBS' "60 Minutes" — USA Gymnastics said that it was "appalled that anyone would exploit a young athlete or child in the manner alleged" and that it had cooperated fully with the FBI. 
The organization also said that it had hired Deborah Daniels, a former U.S. attorney for southern Indiana and assistant attorney general in the administration of President George W. Bush, to conduct a "comprehensive independent review of USA Gymnastics bylaws, policies, procedures and practices." 
Daniels is expected to submit her recommendations in the spring or early summer, USA Gymnastics said. 
"Nothing is more important to USA Gymnastics than protecting young people," the organization said. "Their health and well-being is our priority, and USA Gymnastics is committed to doing everything we can to promote a safe environment for athletes." Alex Johnson
